text: hi everyone anthony cartano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new richard
dawson and circle album henke this is a
brand new lp from uk singer songwriter
richard dawson who is teaming up with
the finnish rock band circle on this new
one an experimental and progressive band
that's been putting out records since
about the early 90s dawson actually
teased this kind of surprising crossover
in a recent interview i did with him uh
where he said this new record would lean
kind of progressive and and boy was he
not lying i mean stylistically that's
really uh circles bread and butter but
dawson himself is no stranger to working
loads of experimental and progressive
influences into his very left field
brand of folk music as well his last
proper album the dystopian pre-pandemic
prediction that he came out with in 2019
which was titled 2020 which i guess was
just a little bit off in terms of
predicting
just how awful the immediate future
would be
it turns out the picture
he painted could have just been a lot
grimmer but instrumentally some of the
tracks on this record were some of
dawson's most rock inspired so far and
there was also the uh lockdown album he
came out with the republic of geordi
land which had some pretty abstract but
somewhat unrealized ideas all over it
too so now from there we are on to this
new record with circle and on it we
pretty much get dawson's enchanting
style of songwriting and very eccentric
topic choices his strange but passionate
lead vocals too backed now with a full
nerd prague arsenal of guitars bass
drums synths some electronics as well
and the whole thing is fantastic
featuring the seven lengthy tracks with
intriguing stories packed into each of
them i think this record also serves as
a reminder of progressive rock's
original mission not just to
attain some certain level of technical
proficiency but also to break and
advance past the conventions of rock and
popular music and while these seven
tracks are quite anthemic and
do sit on some tried and true tropes
they're far from conventional the
opening track cooksonia is titled after
a genus of extinct land plants and is
essentially a story about a botanist's
upbringing and education then eventually
leading to this tragic outing where they
and another botanist are traveling with
some specimens that are deteriorating as
they leave the country the whole story
of the song ending in this picture of
desolation and of course the whole tale
is soundtracked by these meditative and
primal drums grim guitar strumming some
sparkling synth passages too to break
the tension not to mention the finish of
the track escalates into this wall of
psychedelic fuzzy folk and this song
overall is a very easy going but
emotional start to a record that gets
more adventurous and urgent as it
continues the song ivy for example is a
multiverse epic that touches down on a
few different narrative points of greek
mythology but the whole thing seems
mostly in reference to the seder silenus
who eventually gives the power to turn
whatever he wanted by touch to gold to
king midas which if you're familiar with
that story you know how tragically that
ends and the music complementing this
track is as dark grand and archaic as i
could have hoped for especially in the
first leg with it sounding like the
soundtrack to a medieval dungeon plus i
love that dawson hits us with these
preposterous but uh kind of amazing
falsettos the whole thing gets even
better as the rhythms and riffs pick up
around the midpoint where the story gets
kind of treacherous around a stoning and
some travel at sea the greek tie-ins
continue on the record with the track
silphium with mentions of apollonia and
cyrene the story itself seems to feature
merchants or travelers on a tiring
journey where they are lost and running
out of food or just not eating the best
of food and outside of dawson's
falsettos hitting a little weak on the
front end the whole first leg of the
track is a throttling thrill ride where
the dire circumstances of the
protagonists in the story translates
really clearly in the middle of the
track there's also a sudden jazz rock
break that goes over really well with
the original riffs and rhythms coming
back for a finale on the back end cylene
is a more meditative cut by comparison
with everything else here with these
very repetitive guitars and pulsating
electronics and i appreciate the whole
thing more in concept than i do in
practice because there are multiple
passages where dawson and circle throw
on top of
this rhythm section
some vocal layers and melodies that seem
almost at odds with the instrumentation
below which i'm sure to a degree was
intentional as it is a bit jarring and
everything else on the record is so
cohesive by comparison but i'm not
really sure if the effect they were
going for really came through but the
last several songs on the record are
some of the strongest here the plant
themes on the lp continue with the track
methuselah which is not only the name of
one of the biggest sequoias on earth but
the track also seems to be a story about
donald rusk curry a researcher and
geographer who was known for in the 60s
having accidentally killed what's known
to be the
oldest living tree the lyrics of the
track give a detailed description as to
how this happened and then immediately
after this realization hits him uh the
whole thing breaks into this pandora's
box of uh frightening refrains and riffs
it gets really grim lily is probably the
most straightforward and clean cut
structurally on the entire lp the hook
hits really hard on this one and with
immediacy now don't get me wrong some of
the group vocals on this thing are
pretty theatrical and campy and dawson's
falsettos won't be for everybody it is
weird but it's still quite catchy even
with some of the operatic vocals on the
bridge and the lyrics being as morbid as
they are then the closing track i really
enjoyed i thought was a rockin and
triumphant finish for the whole thing
comes to a really amazing vocal and
instrumental climax toward the end too
with a circle really going absolutely
insane really making some of the most
wild and raw prague music i've heard in
a while i mean yeah i'm i'm heavily
impressed with this record it's so good
the songwriting the production the
performances
it's just all great so full of
personality so colorful and uh and so
unique lyrically and conceptually i
think dawson hits it out of the park
once again and it just so happens that
circle was the perfect accompaniment to
the whole thing i'm feeling a strong
eight to a light nine on this one
transition have you given this album a
listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review
next hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well over here next to my head
it's
it's another video you can check out hit
that up or the link to subscribe to the
channel anthony fantano richard dawson
forever
